urn:contentItem:5P73-P311-DY0W-4228-00000-00Soldiers Attacked Near Paris; North Korea on Notice as Trump Promises 'Fire and Fury'; Deadly Earthquake in China; New Password Rules;2017-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:09ZLexisNexisSoldiers Attacked Near Paris; North Korea on Notice as Trump Promises 'Fire and Fury'; Deadly Earthquake in China; New Password Rules;LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning to you and hi everybody. Happy Wednesday. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, August 9th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news right now, an attack near Paris, six soldiers are injured after a vehicle plows into them. A massive manhunt is underway right now for the driver of that vehicle.

North Korea is threatening to strike the United States territory of Guam after President Trump put his country on notice.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: North Korea best not make anymore threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will have the very latest on this escalating tension this morning. The news putting global markets on edge, in Asia Overnight, declines across the board. As you can see there, Japan down one and a quarter percent.

Moving over to Europe, markets are under pressure this morning, as you'll see, down almost one percent on the FTSE100. Down one and three quarters percent on the CAC Krones in Paris and the DAX Index in Germany down one and a quarter percent.

In the U.S., Futures indicating a lower opening for the broader averages this morning, the U.S. taking a cue from Europe, the DOW Jones Industrial Average down a quarter of a percent, the S&P500 down one half of one percent, and the Nasdaq down two-third of a percent.

Disney set to weigh on the DOW, that's for sure. The company announcing it will take on Netflix in the streaming wars as third quarter revenue misses analyst's expectations. The stock down three and a half percent right now.

Southwest Airlines hit by a tech outage triggering flight delays along the West Coast. We've got the latest coming out of Southwest.

And so much for complicated computer passwords, the man who created the rule says he got them all wrong, regrets them and that hackers will always be able to break into your computer.

Remembering the Rhinestone Cowboy this morning, Glen Campbell dies after a long battle with Alzheimer's. We will look back at the country music legend's career.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Former Presidential Candidate and Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee. And Rosecliff CEO Managing Partner Mike Murphy. Great to see you.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FMR. ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Good morning Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

MURPHY: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: You too.

BARTIROMO: And wow we came back --

MCDOWELL: I missed you when you're not here, when we're not together.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. But we come back to some big stuff. Governor, what's your take on this escalating situation with North Korea?

HUCKABEE: A lot of people are trying to compare it to the Cuban Missile Crisis but the difference is we were dealing with a regime in the Soviet Union that was very different than North Korea. They knew they had a lot to lose.

Kim Jong-un has really nothing to lose. I mean this is brinkmanship at its worst and I think it's a very delicate situation for us.

BARTIROMO: It is, it's so scary.

MCDOWELL: From the outside looking in though it seems like because the Hermit Kingdom is so isolated that it would -- that it would be possible to isolate and cutoff all the flow of funds. But those sanctions from the United Nations do not go far enough according to many.

MURPHY: I think it's kind of important to point out, this isn't a President Trump issue though, this has been going on for years and years, some that they've allowed to be built up this way. So the fact that we're dealing with it now I think is kind of something that has to be dealt with.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean what else is he supposed to do other than push back with the creation and the implementation of these nuclear warheads now?

HUCKABEE: And I think the key is China. China is the one country that has the leverage, that has the ability and also has the most really in terms of the neighborhood to lose. I think that's where we're going to have to see the leverage supply.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're going to talk more about this this morning. We got a big program ahead.

Coming up this morning, "FOX NEWS" Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano is here. The Governor of Wisconsin, Scott Walker is back with us this morning. Eric Trump's wife, President Trump's daughter-in-law and the Trump for President Senior Adviser, Lara Trump is with us this morning. And Former McDonald's CEO of the U.S., Former Famous Dave CEO, Ed Rensi joins us as well.

Big program ahead so don't miss a moment of it. And we're following breaking news out of the suburbs of Paris this morning where authority say six soldiers were injured after a vehicle deliberately slammed into them before driving off.

Authorities are now searching for that vehicle and its driver. The incident, the very latest of several attacks targeting security forces in France. Joining us right now Trump 2020 Advisory Board Member and Former Navy Seal, Carl Higbie. Carl, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us this morning.

CARL HIGBIE, TRUMP 2020 ADVISORY BOARD MEMBER, FORMER NAVY SEAL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: This is what, the third or fourth attack in Paris or around Paris in the last year.

HIGBIE: They just keep coming. And you know what, like my heart goes out to the people of France but at the end of the day they've allowed this to happen. They've allowed this kind of loose societal grip and the expansion of these extreme views.

I mean, I'm not saying that it was something that it's not but at the end of the day that they've allowed this to expand and they've tolerated this.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We want to find out exactly who's behind this and we don't want to speculate. We do want to talk about North Korea though Carl with you because the country's state land media announced and it was, "Carefully examining plans for a missile strike that would create an enveloping fire around the Western Pacific Island of Guam where the U.S. has a critical Air Force base."

This threat is coming just a day after the U.S. flew a pair of B1 Bombers that took off from Guam over the Korean Peninsula. And then it was just hours after President Trump used the harshest language we've heard yet in his response to recent taunt by North Korea. Listen to this Carl.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: North Korea best not make anymore threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.

He has been very threatening beyond a normal statement. And as I said, they will be met with fire, fury, and frankly, power the likes of which this world has never seen before.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well those high level war of words coming as "FOX NEWS" confirmed reports from U.S. Intelligence agencies that North Korea has in fact successfully miniaturized a nuclear warhead that could fit inside one of its missiles.

Carl Higbie, what do you make of this ratcheting up of the tensions here?

HIGBIE: Well I mean, this is ratcheting up -- as Governor Huckabee had said earlier, these ratcheting up has been happening over the last decade. I mean we stepped off the world's -- the world is in safer place America is strong and when America's in the front.

And this is something that we stepped out of the way and we've allowed this to happen. Much like France has allowed their population to run them up, we've allowed this and we've -- China has allowed this, Russia has allowed this.

We need to step up now and say enough is enough. I mean everyone's shocked when President Trump comes out with strong rhetoric like this. All he's doing is saying, "Stop threatening us." It's not like he's going on the offense here.

But sooner or later we're going to have to do something about it because obviously sanctions haven't worked, we cut away a third of their imports but at the end of the day, all he does is redirect the already limited sources going to his people back to his military complex.

HUCKABEE: You know Carl, I think all of us would love to see a diplomatic solution but it doesn't appear that North Koreans are prone to accepting any diplomacy.

From a military perspective, what are the options that the U.S has? I think a lot of Americans are saying, what could we do militarily that would stop this?

HIGBIE: Yes. Well our military is the population of some small countries out there. So it will -- what we can do is we can park three carrier strike groups off the Coast.

And I wrote about this in an Op-Ed this morning and next time he shoots a missile you shoot it down. The next time he shoots another missile, you shoot that down, you blow up the installation that it came from and you continue to repeat this over and over again.

And I think that Kim Jong, part of the problem is is his military leaders are probably telling him that he is the greatest military, he can't be defeated because they're worried about being executed themselves. So I think part of it is perception internally that we need to combat also with propaganda.

HUCKABEE: Are we dealing with something similar to the Emperor of Japan where it took an atomic bomb? I'm not saying we nuke the place, I'm just saying that it takes something as dramatic so that his own military people finally say, "This isn't going to end well."

HIGBIE: Unfortunately, I think it's going to come to a show force and it may be at the hands of our military blowing up many of their military installations.

I hope that we don't have to take it out on the people because the people suffer so much and I wish we could avoid a conflict but at the end of the day, if he's threatening the United States and Guam with nuclear weapons, we need to do something. Sanctions and talking is not going to make any difference.

MCDOWELL: Well -- but one, because we're talking about the sanctions Carl, does sanctions out of the U.N. even though China did vote for them, they only caught $1 billion of the $3 billion in exports, those could have gone further.

And "The Wall Street Journal" certainly in the editorial page has raised the issue of why did China sign on with these sanctions? Is it because it's worried legitimately so about the United States cracking down on Chinese firms doing business with North Korea and elsewhere?

So there's more to be done on sanctions. This country theoretically would be easy to starve, no pun intended.

HIGBIE: Right. Well that's the thing too. China is kind of stuck in a rock in a hard place. China doesn't want America to go into South -- or into North Korea because then it would have U.S. troops in their borders.

So that's one of the things they do not want. And also they are worried about us sanctioning them or working against their banks and their system but at the end of the day, it's one of those things.

Like China has kind of let this devolved into what it is. China can crush them if they wanted to, they're just not willing to do it.

BARTIROMO: So should we give up on China? I mean is there anything else to do in terms of China and get engaging China further?

HIGBIE: I think we're kind of stuck in a stalemate and I think Ambassador Nikki Hailey did a great job negotiating these sanctions. I saw her the other morning speaking about it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HIGBIE: But I think this is -- I think what's -- the first thing that's going to happen is China's going to come back to the table and say, "Hey, how can we help?" Once we take some sort of military action whether it be shooting down a missile or something to that effect.

I don't advocate for preemptive strike on North Korea at this time but I think we definitely need to start shooting down their missiles because they've made the threat, we need to assume that they are coming at one of our targets or one of our bases or allies so we need to get rid of it.

MURPHY: Hey Carl, it's Mike Murphy. If they do come at one of our bases or one of our allies, doesn't that make President Trump's job that much easier because I don't think there's anyone out there that would say we shouldn't defend ourselves or defend our interest.

So while it's stable rattling back and forth, people can knock President Trump. But once they attack us, I think we have to at that point respond, right?

HIGBIE: Well like the Governor said, this is -- I mean this is indicative of the world -- the Pre-World War II, Pre-Pearl Harbor Attack. I mean like we were just sitting there waiting trying to avoid getting into a conflict with them and ultimately it cost us Pearl Harbor.

So are we willing to wait that much longer? I mean look, if the left wing media is going to spin this as Donald Trump is a warmonger no matter what. Whether we're attacked or whether we do preemptive strikes.

So in the eyes of the media they're not going to be happy with them but I think this is about keeping the American people safe. And if we can't do that because the left wing media is so amped up at making sure that Donald Trump is the enemy and not actually North Korea itself, I mean we need to start doing what's in the best interest of us and (INAUDIBLE) is scared right now.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's not just the left wing media though. I mean this morning I saw soundbytes of Chuck Schumer, of other leading democrats basically attacking the president and saying this was irresponsible.

And you would think that those people who've been in congress for years even before Donald Trump entered Washington knew the threat that is North Korea and wouldn't pile on but try to help with solutions. Meanwhile there's this new "CBS" -- yes, go ahead Carl.

HIGBIE: Yes. Well Maria, what was irresponsible is people like Chuck Schumer sitting idly by, why Barrack Obama allowed them to expand the technology to get to where we are now. That's their fault and that was irresponsible for them. President Trump is reacting.

HUCKABEE: Carl, I'm confident of the fact that Donald Trump is surrounded by some military experts, Kelly, McMaster, Mattis. These are people who understand not only the full capacity of the U.S. and of North Korea but they've studied this and game this at the table over and over again.

With all due respect to Chuck Schumer which is not a lot, he has no idea what he's doing. This is not a political issue, this is an issue of extraordinary sensitivity and I'm glad that he's surrounded by military people and not just by a bunch of whiny diplomats and politicians.

HIGBIE: Couldn't agree more Governor.

BARTIROMO: It's true, they're treating it like a political issue.

HUCKABEE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Well they make it about Donald Trump's language and his words and rhetoric, whatever you want to call it and not make it about the issue at hand. And that is North Korea from administration to administration.

We have stepped back and allowed the Hermit Kingdom to develop and intercontinental ballistic missile and miniaturized warheads that could deliver a nuclear vice potential to the United States, period. And the fact that that is still loss on many people and government and outside of government is mindboggling.

BARTIROMO: It really is. And to treat it as a political issue is really so unacceptable. Carl, good to see you. Thanks very much for weighing in here.

HIGBIE: Thanks folks.

BARTIROMO: We'll be watching the developments obviously. Carl Higbie there. Coming up, a technical issue for Southwest Airlines causes major delays. What you need to know before you head to the airport, that's next.

And then remembering Glen Campbell, the legendary singer famous for combining country and pop music has died at the age of 81. We'll take a look at his achievements straight ahead, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news out of China this morning, Cheryl Casone with the details of a devastating earthquake, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Yes. So Maria, this very strong earthquake in Southwest China has killed at least 19 people, about 250 others also injured. Forty of those injured in serious conditions as quake knocking out power and phone networks which is right now complicating search efforts.

We're also following Tropical Storm Franklin which is moving into the sea after hitting Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula. Forecasters are saying that Franklin is expected to strengthen into a hurricane before it makes its second landfall on Mexico Central Gulf Coasts.

Meanwhile here in the U.S., heavy rains caused a major flooding down in Houston, Texas. There's been about two dozen water rescues in the area, look at this. The National Weather Service has issued a flashflood watch for the region, that will go through until this morning.

Well a technology issue causing some problems on the West Coast for travelers flying on Southwest Airlines. Southwest says the problem delay about 120 flights last night. All but seven departed after experiencing an average delay of at least 90 minutes.

Those delays reported at Reno Tahoe International Airport, at Sacramento also as well. So we're following that story and the stock shares at Southwest up 10 percent so far this year.

Well finally this morning, the world is mourning. The loss of country legend Glen Campbell, he lost his battle with Alzheimer's.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

GLEN CAMPBELL: Like a rhinestone cowboy, riding out on a horse in a star- spangled rodeo.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Well Campbell became a staple in country music history. His career spend 50 years. Friends and family are remembering Campbell at an outpouring of messages. His long-time friend Dolly Parton Twitted this:

TEXT: Glen Campbell was one of the greatest voices of all time. I will always love you, Glen.

Fellow country music singer Tim McGraw said:

TEXT: Songs, songs, songs, man in a world of good stuff, his was great. In a world of great stuff, his was special.

And his daughter Ashley tweeted this picture which is just -- it's a sad picture:

TEXT: Heartbroken, I owe him everything I am and everything I ever will be. He will be remembered so well and with so much love.

Glen Campbell died in Nashville yesterday. He was surrounded by his family, he was 81 years old Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much Cheryl. I like that picture. I thought that picture said a lot actually.

HUCKABEE: Beautiful picture. Yes.

BARTIROMO: I like it with his hand. Good Arkansas boy?

HUCKABEE: Yes. Came from --

BARTIROMO: Like yourself.

HUCKABEE: -- Billstown, Arkansas near Delight, a suburb of Delight which I'm sure you've never heard off. Not far from where I grew up in Hope, Arkansas. Southwest Arkansas guy, wonderful family. He was like the fifth of twelve kids.

But his agility on the guitar was something a lot of people never understood. He was a studio musician with a famed Wrecking Crew. If you haven't seen the documentary, the Wrecking Crew by Denny Tedesco, one of the best music documentaries I've ever witnessed and it will explain why the music of the '60s were so amazing.

MCDOWELL: I wish all of the obituaries and in remembrance of Glen Campbell because we were talking about it in the break mentioned the Wrecking Crew because it really goes to his musical chops and agility.

HUCKABEE: Unbelievable guitar player.

MCDOWELL: And I know that the surviving members, the Wrecking Crew recorded some of the most famous songs coming out of California and --

HUCKABEE: Basically all the songs coming out of California.

MCDOWELL: Whether it's the Beach Boys or --

HUCKABEE: (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: -- Sonny and Cher. And I know Carol Kaye we're talking about the famous --

HUCKABEE: Yes, greatest bases player ever.

MCDOWELL: Female bassist with the Wrecking Crew. She has sent her remembrance there published online.

HUCKABEE: But Glen Campbell, everything thinks of him as the voice and the singing. He was great at that. He had a distinctive voice.

But, again, as a musician, he was a musician's musician at the top of the game, unbelievable on the guitar.

BARTIROMO: So great to hear all of that.

HUCKABEE: Yes, great man.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll take a break. When we come back, how safe is your password? The man who wrote the rule now says he regrets his original advice. The new guidelines on passwords, next.

And then one restaurant is dangerously cheesy, the whacky menu items at the new Cheetos Cafe, straight ahead. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Does your password contain at least one capital letter, a number, and a symbol? Why your strong password is not really that strong at all. Tracee Carrasco with all the details here, Tracee.

TRACEE CARRASCO, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning. Yes. The man who wrote the go-to guide for federal agencies, universities, and large companies looking for password, setting rules to follow now says he was wrong.

Bill Burr now retired from the National Institute of Standards and Technology says you don't need to make up funny words, use a letter, number, uppercase, and lowercase letter, and a special character like an exclamation point.

He also said your password doesn't need an expiration date because all of these rules do very little for security and don't keep the hackers away. The NIST revised the guidelines in June and now say to use long, easy to remember phrases. And user should only be forced to change passwords if there's a sign they may have been stolen. It makes sense.

BARTIROMO: And how do you know if your password is stolen?

CARRASCO: Well first of all obviously if it doesn't work. If you start getting random messages like antivirus messages, if you get unwanted browser tools, all of these show that your password may have been compromised.

MURPHY: Bank account is empty.

CARRASCO: Yes. Identity stolen.

HUCKABEE: Yes, I got hacked but the thieves were spending less than I was on my credit card. So I never reported it. So why bother.

MCDOWELL: But you -- this is slightly different but I think that the efforts by financial institutions and other institution to protect your identity, they overstepped. I went to take out a little bit of cash from an ATM when I was in Virginia and it wouldn't let me take the cash out because it automatically assumed that I was -- that the card had been stolen.

BARTIROMO: That you weren't there.

MCDOWELL: But the card had been stolen and that the pass code had been compromised. That -- and it wasn't much money either, there was a few hundred dollars.

HUCKABEE: Dagen, you just didn't have any money in your account. That's why they didn't let you have any money.

MCDOWELL: I immediately got a call from this bank that I increasingly despise and, again, the -- if you make any mistake -- if you put the wrong password in a couple times you get locked out.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MURPHY: Thanks for losing a ton of money from this fraud because when money's taken out of your account by a hacker, it's not your responsibility. Ultimately the bank eats it so they'd rather aggravate you then lose money on the other side.

MCDOWELL: Aggravate me and I'll be walking across the street to the bank next door.

MURPHY: Good point.

BARTIROMO: All right. Tracee thank you. Tracee Carrasco there. We'll take a break. When we come back, Disney saying goodbye to Netflix ending its movie distribution deal with the streaming company. What does it mean for the future of TV and how will Disney create its own streaming service?

Plus, some coffee lovers are going nuts over a new drink at Starbucks. Details on the new frapuccino inspired by Mexico, straight ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Happy Wednesday everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 6:30a.m. on the East Coast.

On the brink, President Trump promising fire and fury against North Korea if the Hermit Kingdom continues with its threat against the United States.

The country is now responding with state media reporting it is considering a missile strike around the Western Pacific Island of Guam where the U.S. has a critical air force base.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We woke up to the media reports of North Korea's talk of revenge on the United States and the so-called new found technology that allows them to target Guam and attack or threat on Guam is a threat or attack on the United States.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The news putting global markets on edge. In Asia overnight, declines across the board as you can see, the Nikkei in Japan and the Kospi in Korea, the worst performers. In Europe this morning, markets are under pressure there as well, taking a cue from Asia.

The European indices are down between three-quarters of one percent and almost two percent in Paris, and in the U.S. futures indicating a lower opening for the broader averages as you can see. The Dow Jones Industrial Average down a fraction with the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ down a round and a half a percent of piece. An arrest made in the shooting death of the Missouri police officer.

The very latest says the suspect has taken into custody, following a manhunt that lasted several days. And new details this morning, in Taylor Swift's case, against the former radio DJ, why he's coming under fire for changing his story. Disney cuts the cord and its deal with Netflix, why Mickey and Company are planning to launch their own streaming services and not give any films to Netflix.

Talk about perfectly cooked. How you can now get your luxury meal covered in Cheetos. And next step, Super Bowl. The details, as the New England Patriots become the first NFL team with its own plane, all that coming up this morning. And our top story first this half an hour, earnings and focus on Wall Street this morning.

The parent company of the Fox Business Network 21st Century Fox set to report after the bell tonight, while Kohl's, Macy's and Snap, among the names due out tomorrow. Disney beat earnings expectations last night while missing on revenue. The big story was the company's bombshell streaming reveal to combat its cable woes.

The company is one working on two new services, one for ESPN Sports Programming and another for its movies and TV shows, which means Disney is pulling its content from Netflix to start its own streaming service. The announcement a huge blow to the streaming giant which is down, Netflix this morning, down almost four percent in the pre-market.

The news quickly overshadowed Netflix a surprise deal for a talk show with late night legend, David Letterman. Joining us right now is, Alpine Funds Portfolio Manager, Sarah Hunt. And Sarah, the race to the stringing supremacies certainly heating up, I know you own technology, do you also own Netflix and some of the streaming in media or Disney?

SARAH HUNT, MANAGER, ALPINE FUNDS PORTFOLIO: So, we're dividend players, so a lot of those companies are not paying dividends right now. So, we would own something like an Apple, which says they (INAUDIBLE) Microsoft but we wouldn't own something like a Netflix here.

And I think that this just shows you also the tension between, is the content -- who is going to be in charge of what's going to happen and I think that this is a big -- when I saw these numbers last night, and when I saw the announcement from Disney, I thought, this is going to be interesting because Netflix is one of those companies that's held up very well. So let's see how that goes on the back of this, and whether or not other people think about following suit.

BARTIROMO: What about the broader markets? What do you think?

HUNT: I think, what it appears, where we've had some really nice earnings for Q2, right? The first half of this year has been really good relative to the last couple of years where you had barely, stagnant earnings. So, I think, that's been very supportive.

But I also think that the market is expecting a lot of things to happen on the political front and the question of whether or not they are going to happen, becomes one that becomes more and more important as we get through the balance of this year.

I also think as we enter into the second half of the year, let's see if we -- what people start saying about next year. And I think that there is some concern that valuations are at pretty high level and so, therefore, you have to see continued growth or some changes on the other economic fronts.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO & FOUNDER, ROSECLIFF VENTURES: I agree with you on the growth front, that we need growth to keep crisis where they are. But, I would kind of disagree on the political front. I think where we are right now the market is supported up here at these levels by the earnings growth we have seen.

I think if you get something out of Washington would actually be a next leg higher in the market, because I don't really see it being priced in here. I think the numbers can't support it. But then when you see a company like Disney that misses on numbers, the market is going to punish that stock and that's what you're seeing this morning.

HUNT: We have also seen -- there was an interesting report yesterday that talked a lot about how companies are reacting to positive surprises and that they're not reacting as well the positive surprises that they have in the last couple of years. And that might also tell you that there's a little bit of push to what do I get to that next increment? So maybe that's that, but I also think that people started build in some numbers into '18 on tax reform that may have to come out. We will see how that goes.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: If you're looking now, if you think this market is overvalued or a lot of the really popular stocks are overvalued, and you're looking for ballast, you're looking for something to offset the risk in your equity portfolio, can you really put money in treasuries at this point, if you look at the yield on the 10-year treasury, it's below 2.3 percent, those are also rich and theoretically, if you had both markets go the wrong way on you, that's all she wrote.

HUNT: Yes, and you probably have more risk in Treasuries if they go against you because the change in interest rates because they're so -- the rates are so low now. It's probably more problematic on price. I think that a lot of the stocks underneath the big tech names and some of the big stocks in the averages have actually gotten.

You've seen a lot of stocks actually come down in the last six months on the retail side, on energy, there have been places where there is room. Now, there's also some threats there which is why those stocks have gotten cheaper. But I think there are places to look in the defense stocks while they are expensive, if you look at what's going on right now, I think that there's some places there that you can look.

And it's the same problem that everyone has had for the last couple of years. Where do you put your money? Where you've driven interest rates low across not only the U.S., but international, it's even worse. You get negative rates across parts of Europe, so that's even harder for people looking to put money to work.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FORMER GOVERNOR OF ARKANSAS: Sarah, let me just ask this, if Congress were to actually get tax reform done, does that super charge the market in all the sectors? Does that really make that kind of difference?

MURPHY: I think, for sure, it does, Governor, if I could weigh in on that, because that gives all companies a tax break, it gives more companies increased earnings, just balance sheets will look better from that. Now, you have seen in this market the reason why at all-time highs, is that you're seeing rotations.

When people sell energy or they sell retail, they are putting that money in large cap tech, or they are putting that money in the financials, in the banks. So I think, money would come off the side lines, new money would come into the market if that were to happen. I'd think that would push the market higher.

HUNT: I think it would definitely help. I mean, you're definitely -- there's a lot of companies that have a lot of sales overseas. So the companies that would benefit the most are the ones that are primarily U.S.- based because that's where their taxes are going to get better the most. If you could bring some of the money back from overseas, I think there's a lot of cash dropped over there.

There's been a lot of discussions about that back and forth about whether or not, how to bring that back and what do you do with it and do you put parameters around what you do with it. Because I think, that we're still looking for capital spending and that still been a sub par version of the kind of growth that we're looking for in the economic front that's absent what the government can do.

So, if you could bring some of that money back or free up more money from a tax perspective, maybe that's something that starts to kick-start other parts of the economy.

BARTIROMO: Businesses have been sitting on cash because of the regulatory environment largely. But, let me ask you about North Korea, how much of a focus is this for the market? Yesterday, it felt like the market did react, was that what it was reacting to yesterday in your view?

HUNT: It felt like it was reacting but it was still a fairly moderate reaction. Even the Kospi, which you would think of all the places where you would see a bigger --

BARTIROMO: What kind of a wild card does this represent for markets?

HUNT: I think the market has seen so many different wild cards in the last year or two that it's very -- it needs to see something that feels more like, other than rhetoric for it to be more of an impact, but I also think you're getting out of earning season.

So from a catalyst standpoint, you've taken that off the table. So maybe August, which can be a tough month anyway from a volume perspective, is trickier to react to things because you have less trading going on and so, therefore, you might see a bigger reaction. But so far, I wouldn't say that this is a huge reaction thus far.

MCDOWELL: If you want safety in your portfolio, erase the issue of 10-year treasuries, want a little bit of security, less risk, what do you buy at this point? Because you have vast numbers of asset classes that look expensive, not wildly overvalued.

HUNT: So we're (INAUDIBLE) stock mutual funds that basically on dividends. So we would look for higher dividend stocks in places where you may have seen some corrections already. You know, MBP, something like that, but I agree with you, I think it's very difficult and I think that that's part of the problem.

And if you look at credit spreads, they have gotten incredibly tight, which is telling you, you know, how yield has been chased down both in the U.S. and in Europe, in Europe, it's even worse. The high yields spread over governments, because governments in some cases are almost nothing negligible or negative.

So I think that it is a really challenging period of time and to be putting together a portfolio if you're an insurance company or somebody else who is trying to then work out pensions later, is a very big challenge in this environment.

BARTIROMO: Did you get a sense of the rest of the year from what you just heard in the second-quarter earnings reports, second quarter profits up 11 percent or so, revenue up 6 percent or so. What about the rest of the year, did you get a sense of their guidance?

HUNT: I would say that it was pretty positive, although what was interesting is, a lot of people who had beats in the second quarter, didn't want to raise full year guidance. So that's telling you that maybe the back half of the year isn't as strong or they would rather be cautious and let themselves be in a position where they can beat earnings again, because what also happens --

BARTIROMO: And they want to see what's going to come out of Washington.

HUNT: Right. And what also happens is that the analysts take numbers down in the middle of the quarter, for next quarter and they end up coming back up in the -- there's a lot of gaming that goes on in that respect. But I would say that they are --I didn't hear a lot of very cautionary second- half statements. I heard more, you know, we are doing pretty well and we're pretty optimistic about the next few months.

MCDOWELL: And the executives are talking less about President Trump on -- at least, early analysis of all the conference calls. You just heard less discussion about Washington and about President Trump, so they are sticking to their knitting, so to speak.

HUCKABEE: Which is a good thing.

MCDOWELL: Right, exactly.

BARTIROMO: Four billion dollars in assets under management, are you fully invested?

HUNT: We are.

BARTIROMO: Great. Sarah, great to see you.

HUNT: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining us this morning, Sarah Hunt, there. Coming up, police arrest the suspect who allegedly reportedly shot and killed the cop in Missouri. The details on what lead to that capture, next. And then, Taylor Swift's going to court after she claims that Colorado DJ groped her. The opening statement for her lawyer made, coming up, back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, futures indicating a lower opening for the broader averages, take a look, Dow Industrial set to open down about 30 points, NASDAQ also down 30 points, that's one-half of one percent. We are looking at a few names on the move, Priceline is one to watch. The stock is falling following the company's latest earnings release.

Earnings of $15.14 a share, topped expectations but the stock has been weighed down by weak guidance for the third quarter. The shares are down better than seven percent right now. We're watching Office Depot this morning, set to report its second quarter earnings before the bell this morning. Analysts are expecting earnings of $0.08 a share.

Shares of Office Depot are up better than 70 percent in the last year, good-looking chart there. A manhunt in Missouri for a police officer is over, police officer killer. Cheryl Casone with the details, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. So, Maria, a suspect wanted in the fatal shooting of a Missouri police officer over the weekend was arrested last night. Ian McCarthy had been on the run for nearly two days. He was arrested for shooting Officer Gary Michael that happened after a traffic stop, Sunday night. McCarthy has been charged with first- degree murder.

Well, a former DJ denies ever touching Taylor Swift's backside on the opening day of, we call it the groping trial. David Mueller testifying he may have touched Swift's rib cage or a rib, she says otherwise. He's seeking at least $3 million. He's accusing the singer of getting him fired. Courtroom sketches show the pop star sitting not far from Mueller yesterday. Swift's lawyers saying the evidence of the assault is overwhelming.

Well, Starbucks launching a drink that's (INAUDIBLE) it's rooted in Mexico. It's called the Horchata, it's almond milk Frappuccino, that's basically what it is. It's a blend of Almond milk, cinnamon syrup, coffee, yes, whipped cream, caramel, and then cinnamon and sugars on top. I'll be checking that out at participating locations here in New York. Anyway, you can get it in the U.S. and Canada for extra, folks. Here is the stock. It's under pressure in the premarket just slightly, 54.04.

And then finally, let's proceed on the food thing, Cheetos fans are going to be in heaven over the next week, three days to be specifically. A Cheetos-themed restaurant is going to open in New York City between August 15th and 17th. The menu for the Cheetos pop-up restaurant designed Anne Burrell from the Food Network. There she is, her hair and all. I love Anne Burrell. Cheetos tacos, Cheetos fried pickles, Maria, Cheetos cheesecake. I know you're interested, maybe not. Anyway, random offerings of Cheetos.

BARTIROMO: All right. Good news. Dagen, do you like that, Cheetos?

MCDOWELL: On occasion. It's like one of those ribs and things. You just --

BARTIROMO: On Occasion. OK.

MCDOWELL: They would like you just, you know, sitting in the airport and then all of a sudden, it's like, whoa! You get hit with that wave of needing some Cheetos. Horchata is delicious. If you go into authentic Mexican restaurants here in the United States, they will serve it. I think it's usually made from rice milk rather than almond milk.

BARTIROMO: I like the almond milk idea.

HUCKABEE: That's just one more thing to slow down things at Starbucks.

MCDOWELL: They're hyper sweet, by the way.

HUCKABEE: For those of us who just want a stinking cup of coffee, we've got to stand behind these people who are asking for things that are more complicated than the formula for a nuclear weapon.

MURPHY: And it's amazing. As the country goes to healthier options, Starbucks puts these drinks out that have thousands of calories.

(CROSSTALK)

HUCKABEE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: A horchata is extremely, extremely sweet. And I haven't tasted this one, but the traditional horchata is.

MURPHY: You don't need a doughnut to dunk in there.

HUCKABEE: That's exactly right.

MURPHY: It was the doughnut inside.

HUCKABEE: Drinking your doughnuts. Now, get this -- I mean, seriously, look at the calorie content, it's just as --

BARTIROMO: But how do they keep turning out these products and people are buying them even in this new era of --

MURPHY: I will tell you. Millennials, children, even teenagers, are going to Starbucks. They'll spend $4.00 or $5.00 for a Frappuccino and mixed whipped thing. And Starbucks has a secret menu that's not posted and kids access that on their phones, and they love it. I can speak to that.

HUCKABEE: It's elitism. Elitism and (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: So, their parents will say no, no, you're not going to Starbucks. You're going to drink water and like it.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: All right. Coming up, it is not a bird, it is the new Patriots plane. A behind-the-scenes look at the two, yes, two Boeing jets the football team just purchased. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: And now this, you're out, Major League Baseball has suspended one of the most experienced umpires. Jared Max with the details here. Jared, good morning.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS CHANNEL SPORTSCASTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. Joe West has been a Major League ump since 1976. He's not 64 year's old and he's become a baseball celebrity of sorts, as we saw at the all-star game last month. Remember this when Nelson Cruz asked for a photo with West just after he stepped to the plate. Everyone loves country Joe West, right? Wrong.

West has been suspended three games without pay by Major League Baseball because when asked by USA Today last month, who's the biggest complainer in the game? Joe West said, it's got to be Adrian Beltre. Every pitch you call that's a strike, he says, "Whoa, whoa, whoa!" I had a game with him recently and the pitch was right down the middle. He tells me, "That ball is outside. I told him, "You may be a great baseball player, but you're the worst umpire in the league. You stink." Suspended three games without pay.

Is there a way to make football a safer sport? A Seattle-based sports equipment company called VICIS has created a new helmet called "Zero1". The helmet's outermost layer deforms like a car bumper, it yields when it's hit and slows impact forces. A second layer, reflex layer of columns that bend and eventually buckle upon impact. A third layer, a very thin hard shell that protects against skull fractures. And the fourth innermost layer is the form layer which conforms to the player's head. Now, the co- founder of the company, Dave Marver, says Zero1 makes a thump noise on impact, not a crack. He says the sound of the game is going to change. Interestingly, I was told yesterday by forensic pathologists Dr. Bennett Omalu who Will Smith portrayed in the movie, Concussion, "Helmets prevent only catastrophic injuries that could cause sudden and unexpected death on the field.

Off the field, August 23rd, on the streets of New York City, 5:00 p.m. at the heart of rush hour, a protest rally has been planned to take place outside the NFL League offices on Park Avenue in honor of Colin Kaepernick because he's still unemployed. While filmmaker Spike Lee tweeted this poster for the event yesterday, Spike Lee later clarified on Twitter that he is not the one in charge of this protest that will take place, again, outside the NFL League offices of the 23rd. Right --- again, right in 5:00 p.m. That ought to be fun to stay on the east side at that point of the day.

HUCKABEE: That would really (INAUDIBLE) and influence people, won't it? Absolutely.

MAX: Last night, I got to attend an event, former New York Giant, George Martin, spent 14 years with the team, walked 3,000 miles across the country to raise money for first responders for 9/11, spoke about his time going across the country as an African-American from the deep south. He was concerned I might run into trouble somewhere along the way and he stressed that what he saw is how much more that we are the same than divided. And that really rang true to me.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MURPHY: Absolutely. And if you're going live in this country to not stand for our national anthem, you know, I have a problem with it. And if I owned the team, I wouldn't want someone to express their views like that, so I think a team owner has the right to not bring in Colin Kaepernick. So, when he protest that, I will avoid at all cost.

MAX: And like I still believe that I don't think he wants to play in the NFL. When you look at the comments that he has made, why would -- you know, you're talking about calling owners, slave owners, does he really want to work in this league for anything, and why did he opt out of his contract with the 49ers. He could be signed up right now playing and he's not.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. Meanwhile, my favorite story of sports this morning is about what the New England Patriots are doing. They bought two new huge planes, Boeing 767. The team will be first in the NFL to have its own planes rather than charter them.

MAX: That's so cool. It's great. Well, it's --

BARTIROMO: Leave it to Bob Crest.

MAX: A great reward for that Super Bowl 51 comeback. It'll have all the designs, the Super Bowl Trophies, the Lombardi Trophies. Every seat on the flight is a first-class seat, and some recline all the way and it will help the players recover from the games.

HUCKABEE: Yes. But there's one big problem, Jared. You know, the reports are that the plane will not be pressurized, they're going to keep the planes deflated as they fly.

(LAUGHTER)

MAX: I knew something was coming. I knew it was coming.

BARTIROMO: Oh, god.

HUCKABEE: They have a soft landing.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: A very good one. That's a very good one.

MCDOWELL: Why don't more teams -- why don't they already own their aircraft before now?

MAX: Somebody -- that's like somebody said before the New York Yankees started the YES Network, why don't more teams have their own networks, they can control a lot more revenue and I get --

MCDOWELL: All the NASCAR drivers for the most part, at the top tour of the series, they have their own private jets, and they fly -- they lease some of them very often, but they fly to the racetracks on the weekend to these -- in these small private aircrafts where there's a gulf stream.

MAX: Right. Golfers, too, get crazy like that.

MURPHY: I would like to see a lot more of this now, Patriots did it, now, I think you'll see more and more teams.

MAX: It would have made sense if it'd be the Jets, but, you know, they're the Jets.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: All right, Jared. Thank you, Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports in Fox News Headlines 24/7 or Sirius XM 115.

Still to come, researchers make a gigantic discovery. The new dinosaur fossils found and then the biggest ever recorded on earth. The details next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, right here, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Thousands of American soldiers threatened. North Korea ramps up its rhetoric against the United States, targeting the Island of Guam. This, after President Trump warned of unprecedented action.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: North Korea best not make any more threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.

BARTIROMO: The news putting global markets on edge. In Asia overnight, declines across the board. The Nikkei Average in Japan down 1-1/4 percent. The KOSPI in Korea down better than one percent. In Europe, markets are also under pressure this morning. Take a look at the indices down between two-thirds of a percent on the FT-100 to down 1-1/2 percent on the CAC Quarante in Paris. In the U.S., Futures indicating a lower opening for stock prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is set to open down about 25 points. NASDAQ down one-half of a percent, down 30 points right now.

And we have breaking news out of France to report this morning.

urn:contentItem:5P73-P311-DY0W-4258-00000-00Soldiers Attacked Near Paris; North Korea on Notice as Trump Promises 'Fire and Fury'; Deadly Earthquake in China; New Password Rules;2017-08-09T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:26:09ZLexisNexisSoldiers Attacked Near Paris; North Korea on Notice as Trump Promises 'Fire and Fury'; Deadly Earthquake in China; New Password Rules;LanhamFULL TEXT

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good morning to you and hi everybody. Happy Wednesday. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Wednesday, August 9th. Your top stories right now, 6:00a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news right now, an attack near Paris, six soldiers are injured after a vehicle plows into them. A massive manhunt is underway right now for the driver of that vehicle.

North Korea is threatening to strike the United States territory of Guam after President Trump put his country on notice.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: North Korea best not make anymore threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will have the very latest on this escalating tension this morning. The news putting global markets on edge, in Asia Overnight, declines across the board. As you can see there, Japan down one and a quarter percent.

Moving over to Europe, markets are under pressure this morning, as you'll see, down almost one percent on the FTSE100. Down one and three quarters percent on the CAC Krones in Paris and the DAX Index in Germany down one and a quarter percent.

In the U.S., Futures indicating a lower opening for the broader averages this morning, the U.S. taking a cue from Europe, the DOW Jones Industrial Average down a quarter of a percent, the S&P500 down one half of one percent, and the Nasdaq down two-third of a percent.

Disney set to weigh on the DOW, that's for sure. The company announcing it will take on Netflix in the streaming wars as third quarter revenue misses analyst's expectations. The stock down three and a half percent right now.

Southwest Airlines hit by a tech outage triggering flight delays along the West Coast. We've got the latest coming out of Southwest.

And so much for complicated computer passwords, the man who created the rule says he got them all wrong, regrets them and that hackers will always be able to break into your computer.

Remembering the Rhinestone Cowboy this morning, Glen Campbell dies after a long battle with Alzheimer's. We will look back at the country music legend's career.

All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to talk all about it, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell. Former Presidential Candidate and Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee. And Rosecliff CEO Managing Partner Mike Murphy. Great to see you.

MIKE HUCKABEE, FMR. ARKANSAS GOVERNOR: Good morning Maria.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

MIKE MURPHY, CEO AND MANAGING PARTNER, ROSECLIFF: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Great to see you.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

MURPHY: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: You too.

BARTIROMO: And wow we came back --

MCDOWELL: I missed you when you're not here, when we're not together.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. But we come back to some big stuff. Governor, what's your take on this escalating situation with North Korea?

HUCKABEE: A lot of people are trying to compare it to the Cuban Missile Crisis but the difference is we were dealing with a regime in the Soviet Union that was very different than North Korea. They knew they had a lot to lose.

Kim Jong-un has really nothing to lose. I mean this is brinkmanship at its worst and I think it's a very delicate situation for us.

BARTIROMO: It is, it's so scary.

MCDOWELL: From the outside looking in though it seems like because the Hermit Kingdom is so isolated that it would -- that it would be possible to isolate and cutoff all the flow of funds. But those sanctions from the United Nations do not go far enough according to many.

MURPHY: I think it's kind of important to point out, this isn't a President Trump issue though, this has been going on for years and years, some that they've allowed to be built up this way. So the fact that we're dealing with it now I think is kind of something that has to be dealt with.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean what else is he supposed to do other than push back with the creation and the implementation of these nuclear warheads now?

HUCKABEE: And I think the key is China. China is the one country that has the leverage, that has the ability and also has the most really in terms of the neighborhood to lose. I think that's where we're going to have to see the leverage supply.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're going to talk more about this this morning. We got a big program ahead.

Coming up this morning, "FOX NEWS" Senior Judicial Analyst, Judge Andrew Napolitano is here. The Governor of Wisconsin, Scott Walker is back with us this morning. Eric Trump's wife, President Trump's daughter-in-law and the Trump for President Senior Adviser, Lara Trump is with us this morning. And Former McDonald's CEO of the U.S., Former Famous Dave CEO, Ed Rensi joins us as well.

Big program ahead so don't miss a moment of it. And we're following breaking news out of the suburbs of Paris this morning where authority say six soldiers were injured after a vehicle deliberately slammed into them before driving off.

Authorities are now searching for that vehicle and its driver. The incident, the very latest of several attacks targeting security forces in France. Joining us right now Trump 2020 Advisory Board Member and Former Navy Seal, Carl Higbie. Carl, good to see you, thanks so much for joining us this morning.

CARL HIGBIE, TRUMP 2020 ADVISORY BOARD MEMBER, FORMER NAVY SEAL: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: This is what, the third or fourth attack in Paris or around Paris in the last year.

HIGBIE: They just keep coming. And you know what, like my heart goes out to the people of France but at the end of the day they've allowed this to happen. They've allowed this kind of loose societal grip and the expansion of these extreme views.

I mean, I'm not saying that it was something that it's not but at the end of the day that they've allowed this to expand and they've tolerated this.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We want to find out exactly who's behind this and we don't want to speculate. We do want to talk about North Korea though Carl with you because the country's state land media announced and it was, "Carefully examining plans for a missile strike that would create an enveloping fire around the Western Pacific Island of Guam where the U.S. has a critical Air Force base."

This threat is coming just a day after the U.S. flew a pair of B1 Bombers that took off from Guam over the Korean Peninsula. And then it was just hours after President Trump used the harshest language we've heard yet in his response to recent taunt by North Korea. Listen to this Carl.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: North Korea best not make anymore threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.

He has been very threatening beyond a normal statement. And as I said, they will be met with fire, fury, and frankly, power the likes of which this world has never seen before.

BARTIROMO: I like the almond milk idea.

HUCKABEE: That's just one more thing to slow down things at Starbucks.

MCDOWELL: They're hyper sweet, by the way.

HUCKABEE: For those of us who just want a stinking cup of coffee, we've got to stand behind these people who are asking for things that are more complicated than the formula for a nuclear weapon.

MURPHY: And it's amazing. As the country goes to healthier options, Starbucks puts these drinks out that have thousands of calories.

(CROSSTALK)

HUCKABEE: Yes.

MCDOWELL: A horchata is extremely, extremely sweet. And I haven't tasted this one, but the traditional horchata is.

MURPHY: You don't need a doughnut to dunk in there.

HUCKABEE: That's exactly right.

MURPHY: It was the doughnut inside.

HUCKABEE: Drinking your doughnuts. Now, get this -- I mean, seriously, look at the calorie content, it's just as --

BARTIROMO: But how do they keep turning out these products and people are buying them even in this new era of --

MURPHY: I will tell you. Millennials, children, even teenagers, are going to Starbucks. They'll spend $4.00 or $5.00 for a Frappuccino and mixed whipped thing. And Starbucks has a secret menu that's not posted and kids access that on their phones, and they love it. I can speak to that.

HUCKABEE: It's elitism. Elitism and (INAUDIBLE)

MCDOWELL: So, their parents will say no, no, you're not going to Starbucks. You're going to drink water and like it.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: All right. Coming up, it is not a bird, it is the new Patriots plane. A behind-the-scenes look at the two, yes, two Boeing jets the football team just purchased. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: And now this, you're out, Major League Baseball has suspended one of the most experienced umpires. Jared Max with the details here. Jared, good morning.

JARED MAX, FOX NEWS CHANNEL SPORTSCASTER: Hey, good morning, Maria. Joe West has been a Major League ump since 1976. He's not 64 year's old and he's become a baseball celebrity of sorts, as we saw at the all-star game last month. Remember this when Nelson Cruz asked for a photo with West just after he stepped to the plate. Everyone loves country Joe West, right? Wrong.

West has been suspended three games without pay by Major League Baseball because when asked by USA Today last month, who's the biggest complainer in the game? Joe West said, it's got to be Adrian Beltre. Every pitch you call that's a strike, he says, "Whoa, whoa, whoa!" I had a game with him recently and the pitch was right down the middle. He tells me, "That ball is outside. I told him, "You may be a great baseball player, but you're the worst umpire in the league. You stink." Suspended three games without pay.

Is there a way to make football a safer sport? A Seattle-based sports equipment company called VICIS has created a new helmet called "Zero1". The helmet's outermost layer deforms like a car bumper, it yields when it's hit and slows impact forces. A second layer, reflex layer of columns that bend and eventually buckle upon impact. A third layer, a very thin hard shell that protects against skull fractures. And the fourth innermost layer is the form layer which conforms to the player's head. Now, the co- founder of the company, Dave Marver, says Zero1 makes a thump noise on impact, not a crack. He says the sound of the game is going to change. Interestingly, I was told yesterday by forensic pathologists Dr. Bennett Omalu who Will Smith portrayed in the movie, Concussion, "Helmets prevent only catastrophic injuries that could cause sudden and unexpected death on the field.

Off the field, August 23rd, on the streets of New York City, 5:00 p.m. at the heart of rush hour, a protest rally has been planned to take place outside the NFL League offices on Park Avenue in honor of Colin Kaepernick because he's still unemployed. While filmmaker Spike Lee tweeted this poster for the event yesterday, Spike Lee later clarified on Twitter that he is not the one in charge of this protest that will take place, again, outside the NFL League offices of the 23rd. Right --- again, right in 5:00 p.m. That ought to be fun to stay on the east side at that point of the day.

HUCKABEE: That would really (INAUDIBLE) and influence people, won't it? Absolutely.

MAX: Last night, I got to attend an event, former New York Giant, George Martin, spent 14 years with the team, walked 3,000 miles across the country to raise money for first responders for 9/11, spoke about his time going across the country as an African-American from the deep south. He was concerned I might run into trouble somewhere along the way and he stressed that what he saw is how much more that we are the same than divided. And that really rang true to me.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MURPHY: Absolutely. And if you're going live in this country to not stand for our national anthem, you know, I have a problem with it. And if I owned the team, I wouldn't want someone to express their views like that, so I think a team owner has the right to not bring in Colin Kaepernick. So, when he protest that, I will avoid at all cost.

MAX: And like I still believe that I don't think he wants to play in the NFL. When you look at the comments that he has made, why would -- you know, you're talking about calling owners, slave owners, does he really want to work in this league for anything, and why did he opt out of his contract with the 49ers. He could be signed up right now playing and he's not.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. Meanwhile, my favorite story of sports this morning is about what the New England Patriots are doing. They bought two new huge planes, Boeing 767. The team will be first in the NFL to have its own planes rather than charter them.

MAX: That's so cool. It's great. Well, it's --

BARTIROMO: Leave it to Bob Crest.

MAX: A great reward for that Super Bowl 51 comeback. It'll have all the designs, the Super Bowl Trophies, the Lombardi Trophies. Every seat on the flight is a first-class seat, and some recline all the way and it will help the players recover from the games.

HUCKABEE: Yes. But there's one big problem, Jared. You know, the reports are that the plane will not be pressurized, they're going to keep the planes deflated as they fly.

(LAUGHTER)

MAX: I knew something was coming. I knew it was coming.

BARTIROMO: Oh, god.

HUCKABEE: They have a soft landing.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: A very good one. That's a very good one.

MCDOWELL: Why don't more teams -- why don't they already own their aircraft before now?

MAX: Somebody -- that's like somebody said before the New York Yankees started the YES Network, why don't more teams have their own networks, they can control a lot more revenue and I get --

MCDOWELL: All the NASCAR drivers for the most part, at the top tour of the series, they have their own private jets, and they fly -- they lease some of them very often, but they fly to the racetracks on the weekend to these -- in these small private aircrafts where there's a gulf stream.

MAX: Right. Golfers, too, get crazy like that.

MURPHY: I would like to see a lot more of this now, Patriots did it, now, I think you'll see more and more teams.

MAX: It would have made sense if it'd be the Jets, but, you know, they're the Jets.

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: All right, Jared. Thank you, Jared Max. Catch Jared's sports reports in Fox News Headlines 24/7 or Sirius XM 115.

Still to come, researchers make a gigantic discovery. The new dinosaur fossils found and then the biggest ever recorded on earth. The details next hour on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, right here, stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back, good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Wednesday, August 9th. Your top stories right now 7:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Thousands of American soldiers threatened. North Korea ramps up its rhetoric against the United States, targeting the Island of Guam. This, after President Trump warned of unprecedented action.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: North Korea best not make any more threats to the United States. They will be met with fire and fury like the world has never seen.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The news putting global markets on edge. In Asia overnight, declines across the board. The Nikkei Average in Japan down 1-1/4 percent. The KOSPI in Korea down better than one percent. In Europe, markets are also under pressure this morning. Take a look at the indices down between two-thirds of a percent on the FT-100 to down 1-1/2 percent on the CAC Quarante in Paris. In the U.S., Futures indicating a lower opening for stock prices. The Dow Jones Industrial Average is set to open down about 25 points. NASDAQ down one-half of a percent, down 30 points right now.

And we have breaking news out of France to report this morning.
